description:
Amphiplicatus metriothermophilus is a species of thermophilic bacteria that belong to the phylum Firmicutes. It is a Gram-positive, spore-forming, and anaerobic microorganism.

A. metriothermophilus is known for its ability to thrive in moderately high-temperature environments, typically found in geothermal areas or industrial settings where elevated temperatures are present. The optimal growth temperature for this species is around 55-60°C (131-140°F).

Morphologically, A. metriothermophilus cells are rod-shaped and can form endospores, which are resistant structures that allow the bacteria to survive under unfavorable conditions. The cells exhibit a unique "amphiplicatus" structure, referring to the folding of the cell membrane, which is believed to play a role in their thermotolerance.

Genetically, A. metriothermophilus has been studied for its potential in various biotechnological applications, such as the production of thermostable enzymes and the degradation of complex organic compounds. Its ability to thrive in high-temperature environments makes it a valuable model organism for understanding the molecular mechanisms underlying thermophilic adaptations in bacteria.
